fields.aside: Claiming at your full retirement age locks in your full monthly benefit.
Claiming at the earliest year locks in a monthly benefit about 30% below your full retirement amount.
Claiming four years early locks in a benefit about 25% below your full amount.
Claiming three years early locks in a benefit about 20% below your full amount.
Claiming two years early locks in a benefit about 13% below your full amount.
Claiming a year early locks in a benefit about 6.7% below your full amount.
Waiting a year to claim boosts your monthly benefit by about 8%.
Waiting two years to claim boosts your monthly benefit by about 16%.
Waiting until 70 gets you the maximum monthly benefit.

fields.title: Claiming Social Security
fields.h1: Claiming Social Security— a choice to fit your lifestyle
fields.intro: Your claiming decision has a big impact. We're here to help you maximize your lifetime income.

fields.text: Maximum retirement age: Always 70. This is the age at which you will get the maximum possible benefit. You should not claim your benefit after this age.
fields.title: max

fields.text: arly retirement: Any time before your full retirement age. If you claim your benefits before your full retirement age, they will be permanently reduced. The earliest age you can claim your retirement benefit is 62.
fields.title: early

fields.text: Social Security retirement benefits are not designed to be your sole source of retirement income, but waiting even one month will increase your benefits.
fields.title: sole_source

fields.text: We calculate benefit estimates based on the Social Security Administration's Quick Calculator. The SSA uses the date of birth and current income values to build an average lifetime earnings history and calculate benefits. The benefit estimates we provide are only approximations, and are intended solely as a way to show how different claiming dates can affect monthly benefits. Social Security will calculate more accurate benefits estimates based on your actual lifetime earnings if you go to Social Security's sign-up page and create an account.
fields.title: calculations

fields.text: Full retirement age varies between 66 and 67 depending on your date of birth. This is the age at which you will receive your full benefit with no reductions.
fields.title: fra

fields.text: Enter your most recent annual salary. If you are unemployed, enter earnings for the most recent year you were employed.
fields.title: salary

fields.text: Lifetime benefits are calculated by multiplying a chosen monthly benefit by the number of months until you reach 85. This is only a rough estimate, for comparison purposes only, and is not your actual lifetime benefit.
fields.title: lifetime

fields.text: "File and suspend" is a claiming strategy that can be useful for married couples, particularly if one spouse earns more than the other. For details, see Social Security's guide explanation.
fields.title: file_and_suspend

fields.text: The Treasury Department sponsors the myRA program, which provides personal retirement savings accounts, backed by the Treasury, for people who make less than $131,000 a year and don't have access to employer-sponsored retirement plans. For details, see the Treasury's myRA page.
fields.title: myra

fields.title: Sixties
fields.answer_no_a_subhed: Working longer can help you maximize your benefits.
fields.answer_yes_b: Because your Social Security benefit is based on your highest 35 years of earnings, working longer can add higher earnings to your record by replacing years with low earnings. This might be helpful if there were years you were a student, were unemployed, or took time off to care for someone. When you work and wait to claim, you can nearly double your benefits by age 70! Additionally, now’s a good time to take advantage of annual catch-up contributions to 401(k)s or other retirement savings.

fields.title: Expenses
fields.answer_no_a_subhed: It’s good to plan for increased expenses.
fields.answer_yes_b: You’re likely to spend 20 years in retirement and income needs are difficult to predict. During that time, you’ll need savings to pay for expenses like home repairs, medical bills, or even buying a car. Additionally, out-of-pocket health care costs are likely to increase as you get older. One solution is to wait to claim Social Security up to age 70, which increases your benefits. This will help other retirement savings, like 401(k)s, last longer.

fields.title: Income
fields.answer_no_a_subhed: You have time and options to save.
fields.answer_yes_b:
Social Security was never intended to be your only source of retirement income. That means your other sources will need to fill this gap. Two steps you can take to ensure that this gap is as small as possible: 1) wait to claim your Social Security benefits (up to age 70) and 2) after age 50, take advantage of 401(k) annual catch-up contributions.


Did you know retirement savings plans including 401(k)s come with penalties if you take your money out before age 59½? Consider accessing your 401(k) assets later in retirement.
fields.answer_yes_a: Social Security was never intended to be your only source of retirement income. That means your other sources, like savings, a 401(k) or an IRA will need to fill the gap. Waiting to claim your benefits (up to age 70) will ensure that this gap is as small as possible. If you claim before your full retirement age, your monthly benefit is permanently reduced by as much as 30 percent. Claiming early means that you will need to save more on your own for a secure retirement.

Waiting to claim as long as possible (up to age 70) can nearly double your monthly benefit.


You can also cut costs by downsizing to a smaller home or paying off your mortgage.

fields.title: Long life
fields.answer_no_a_subhed: There’s a good chance that you may live into your 80s.
fields.answer_yes_a: The average life expectancy is 84 for men and 87 for women. Because Social Security provides lifetime guaranteed income, it is especially valuable to you in your 80s and beyond. Waiting to claim your Social Security benefits is the best way to cover expenses if you live a long time. Your benefit increases the longer you wait to claim, up to age 70, and are adjusted every year to keep up with the cost of living.
